content.original:
Difference between Management and Administration
Key difference: Administration frames the objectives and policies of an organization. Management implements these policies and objectives.
Management and administration are at times used interchangeably; however, they are two different levels of the organization. The administration is the top level of the organization with the decisive functions. They are responsible for determining the policies and objectives of the organization or the firm. Management, on the other hand is the middle level executive function. They implement the policies and objectives as decided by the administration.
The administration includes the people who are either owners or partners of the firm. They usually contribute to the firm’s capital and earn profits or returns on their investment. The main administrative function is handling the business aspects of the firm, such as finance. Other administrative functions usually include planning, organizing, staffing, directing, controlling and budgeting. Administration must integrate leadership and vision, to organize the people and resources, in order to achieve common goals and objectives for the organization.
Management usually incorporates the employees of the firm who use their skills for the firm in return for remuneration. Management is responsible for carrying out the strategies of the administration. Motivation is the key factor of a management. Management must motivate and handle the employees. It can be said that management is directly under the control of administration.
Further comparison between management and administration:
|
|
Management |
Administration |
|
Definition |
Art of getting things done through others by directing their efforts towards achievement of pre-determined goals. |
Formulation of broad objectives, plans & policies. |
|
Nature |
executing function, doing function |
decision-making function, thinking function |
|
Scope |
Decisions within the framework set by the administration. |
Major decisions of an enterprise as a whole. |
|
Level of authority |
Middle level activity |
Top level activity |
|
Status |
Group of managerial personnel who use their specialized knowledge to fulfill the objectives of an enterprise. |
Consists of owners who invest capital in and receive profits from an enterprise. |
|
Usage |
Used in business enterprises. |
Popular with government, military, educational, and religious organizations. |
|
Influence |
Decisions are influenced by the values, opinions, beliefs and decisions of the managers. |
Influenced by public opinion, government policies, customs etc. |
|
Main functions |
Motivating and controlling |
Planning and organizing |
|
Abilities |
Handles the employees. |
Handles the business aspects such as finance. |

content.optimized:
# Difference between Management and Administration The fundamental distinction between administration and management lies in their organizational roles. Administration operates at the executive or top management level, responsible for establishing objectives and policies with strategic and decisive authority. Management functions at the middle management level, focusing on implementing these policies and objectives through operational activities. | | Management | Administration | |----------------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------| | Definition | The art and science of accomplishing organizational goals through directing and coordinating the efforts of others. | The process of formulating broad organizational objectives, plans, and policies. | | Nature | Operational and execution-oriented function | Strategic decision-making and policy formulation function | | Scope | Tactical decisions within the framework established by administration. | Strategic decisions impacting the enterprise as a whole. | | Level of authority | Middle management level | Executive/top management level | | Status | Comprises professional managers utilizing specialized knowledge to achieve enterprise objectives. | Consists of owners or board members who invest capital and receive profits. | | Usage | Predominantly applied in business enterprises. | Commonly associated with government, military, educational, and religious institutions. | | Influence | Decisions influenced by managerial expertise, organizational culture, and operational constraints. | Influenced by external factors such as public opinion, government regulations, and societal norms. | | Main functions | Motivating, directing, and controlling operational activities. | Planning, organizing, and policy formulation. | | Abilities | Manages human resources and operational processes. | Oversees financial management and strategic resource allocation. | ## Administration Administration typically includes owners or partners who invest capital and receive returns. Its primary responsibilities encompass strategic planning, financial oversight, organizing, staffing, directing, controlling, and budgeting. Administration integrates visionary leadership and governance to coordinate human and material resources, ensuring alignment with organizational goals. Governance plays a crucial role in administration by establishing frameworks and policies that guide organizational conduct, risk management, and compliance. In procurement, governance frameworks ensure transparency, accountability, and ethical standards in purchasing decisions, aligning procurement activities with the organization's strategic objectives and regulatory requirements. ## Management Management generally consists of salaried employees who apply specialized skills to execute the administration’s strategies. Key duties include motivating employees and managing performance under the supervision and authority of the administration. In procurement processes, management is responsible for operationalizing governance policies by overseeing supplier selection, contract management, and purchase execution. Effective procurement management ensures that purchasing decisions are efficient, cost-effective, and compliant with governance standards. # Role of a Supervisor in a Company A supervisor plays a critical role within the management hierarchy as the frontline leader responsible for overseeing team performance and ensuring productivity. Supervisors serve as the vital link between management and employees, facilitating communication, clarifying expectations, and addressing workplace issues promptly. Key responsibilities include monitoring daily operations, conducting training sessions to enhance employee skills, enforcing company policies and procedures, and providing feedback to both employees and higher management. Unlike managers, supervisors typically have limited authority regarding hiring and firing decisions and do not control budgets, focusing instead on operational execution and team coordination. Supervisors maintain workflow efficiency, resolve conflicts, and foster a positive work environment. Their role bridges strategic directives from management with practical employee performance, ensuring organizational goals are met through effective team leadership. # Leadership Training Programs for HR Professionals Leadership training programs tailored for HR professionals bridge the gap between administration and management by developing competencies in strategic decision-making, employee motivation, conflict resolution, and organizational leadership—critical for aligning administrative strategy with managerial execution. ## Examples of Available Courses and Certifications - **Certified Professional in Human Resources (CPHR) Leadership Program:** Focuses on strategic HR leadership and organizational development. - **SHRM Senior Certified Professional (SHRM-SCP):** Emphasizes leadership in HR policy implementation and strategic management. - **Leadership Development for HR Managers:** Covers change management, leadership communication, and employee engagement strategies. - **Online courses on Coursera and LinkedIn Learning:** Offer flexible modules on leadership fundamentals tailored for HR professionals. These programs empower HR professionals to contribute effectively to both management and administration, enhancing organizational performance and sustainability. ## How to Enroll Enrollment is available through accredited HR bodies, universities, and reputable online platforms. HR professionals can apply directly via official portals or seek employer sponsorship. Examples include: - **Certified Professional in Human Resources (CPHR) Leadership Program** via the CPHR Canada website, requiring online application and documentation. - **SHRM Senior Certified Professional (SHRM-SCP)** certification through SHRM’s portal, requiring registration, fees, and eligibility criteria including work experience and education. - University programs like **Leadership Development for HR Managers**, with online or in-person registration through continuing education departments. - Online platforms such as Coursera and LinkedIn Learning offering self-paced enrollment with immediate access. ## Program Schedules and Certification Requirements Most programs offer flexible schedules—including evening classes, weekends, or fully online modules—to accommodate working professionals. Certification typically requires completing coursework, passing exams, and fulfilling practical experience hours. For example, SHRM-SCP candidates must pass a comprehensive exam and maintain ongoing professional development. Universities may require capstone projects or leadership simulations. ## Direct Links and Registration Instructions - CPHR Leadership Program: [https://www.cphr.ca/leadership-program](https://www.cphr.ca/leadership-program) - SHRM-SCP Certification: [https://www.shrm.org/certification](https://www.shrm.org/certification) - Leadership Development for HR Managers (example university): Visit the university’s continuing education webpage and search “HR Leadership Development.” - Coursera Leadership Courses: [https://www.coursera.org/browse/business/leadership](https://www.coursera.org/browse/business/leadership) - LinkedIn Learning Leadership Modules: Accessible via subscription; search “HR leadership.” ## Program Benefits Participants gain advanced leadership skills to align HR initiatives with organizational objectives, improve team productivity, and foster a positive workplace culture. These programs also offer valuable networking opportunities with industry experts and peers, supporting professional growth and knowledge exchange. # Recommended Leadership Books for HR Managers To complement formal training, HR professionals can benefit greatly from authoritative leadership books that provide practical insights and strategies tailored to HR leadership development. Below is a curated list of top leadership books highly recommended for HR managers: - **The Coaching Habit** by Michael Bungay Stanier Offers simple yet powerful coaching techniques that HR leaders can use to develop their teams, foster engagement, and improve performance through effective conversations. - **Work Rules!** by Laszlo Bock Provides an insider’s perspective on innovative HR practices and leadership approaches that drive organizational success, written by the former SVP of People Operations at Google. - **Radical Candor** by Kim Scott Guides HR leaders on building strong relationships through honest communication and giving feedback that is both caring and direct, essential for managing talent and culture. - **The New HR Leader’s First 100 Days** by Alan Collins A practical guide for new HR leaders outlining strategies to quickly establish credibility, build relationships, and drive impactful change within the first critical months. - **Drive: The Surprising Truth About What Motivates Us** by Daniel H. Pink Explores the science of motivation, offering HR leaders insights into how to inspire and engage employees beyond traditional incentives. - **Leaders Eat Last** by Simon Sinek Emphasizes the importance of trust and empathy in leadership, helping HR professionals create environments where people feel safe and valued. - **First, Break All the Rules** by Marcus Buckingham and Curt Coffman Reveals what the best managers do differently based on extensive research, providing HR leaders with evidence-based practices to improve employee engagement and retention. These books serve as valuable resources for HR managers seeking to enhance their leadership capabilities, foster a positive workplace culture, and align HR strategies with organizational goals. # Supervision Training Courses: Enrollment Procedures, Schedules, and Certification Supervision training courses enhance supervisory competencies and are offered by various institutions and platforms. Enrollment typically involves visiting the provider’s website, completing an online registration form, and paying fees. Some courses require prerequisites such as prior management experience or foundational HR training. Schedules vary widely, including self-paced online courses, live virtual sessions, and in-person workshops. For example, the **Certified Supervisor Training Program** by the American Management Association (AMA) offers online and classroom formats with sessions throughout the year. Certification usually requires completing all modules, passing assessments, and demonstrating practical supervisory skills. ## Direct Registration Links and Instructions - AMA Certified Supervisor Training: [https://www.amanet.org/certified-supervisor-training](https://www.amanet.org/certified-supervisor-training) - Coursera Supervision Courses: [https://www.coursera.org/courses?query=supervision](https://www.coursera.org/courses?query=supervision) - LinkedIn Learning Supervision Training: Accessible via subscription; search “supervision skills.” - Local community colleges and professional HR organizations often list supervision courses with step-by-step enrollment guides. ## Certification Requirements Most certifications require completing coursework, passing quizzes or exams, and sometimes submitting a final project or case study. Continuing education credits may be necessary to maintain certification. ## Relevant Supervision Training Materials - Online workshops and webinars on supervisory leadership and team management. - Interactive courses combining theory with real-world case studies to enhance decision-making. - Certification programs complementing leadership training for HR professionals. Integrating supervision training with leadership development equips HR professionals and managers with a well-rounded skill set to oversee teams effectively and contribute to organizational success. # Supervision E-Books and Training Resources In addition to courses, downloadable e-books and training materials support development of supervisory skills, focusing on supervision techniques, communication, performance management, and team leadership. ## Descriptions of Supervision E-Books - *Effective Supervision: A Guide for Managers and Supervisors* offers practical strategies for team management, conflict resolution, and productivity improvement. - *The Supervisor’s Toolkit* provides tools and templates for performance appraisals, coaching, and employee development. - *Fundamentals of Supervision* covers essential skills including delegation, motivation, and time management. ## How to Access or Download These resources are available through professional HR associations, online bookstores, and educational platforms. Many offer free or low-cost downloads upon registration, while others provide comprehensive training packages including e-books, video tutorials, and interactive modules. # London Business School Governance Faculty and Programs London Business School (LBS) is renowned for its distinguished governance faculty, comprising leading scholars and practitioners with expertise in corporate governance, organizational leadership, and business ethics. Faculty research covers board dynamics, executive compensation, stakeholder engagement, and governance reforms. Many faculty members hold leadership roles in academic and professional governance organizations, contributing to global thought leadership and policy development. Their research informs best practices, bridging theory and real-world governance application. LBS offers governance-focused programs designed to equip business leaders and HR professionals with advanced knowledge and skills. Courses cover corporate governance frameworks, ethical leadership, risk management, and strategic decision-making. Programs such as **Executive Education in Corporate Governance** and **Leadership in Business** provide practical insights and case studies to help participants navigate complex governance challenges. ### Procurement Governance Frameworks and Case Studies A key area within governance is procurement governance, which establishes the policies, procedures, and controls that ensure purchasing activities are conducted ethically, transparently, and in alignment with organizational goals. Procurement governance frameworks define roles and responsibilities, approval hierarchies, risk management protocols, and compliance requirements to safeguard organizational resources and reputation. Governance in procurement ensures that purchasing decisions are made with accountability, fairness, and strategic alignment, reducing risks such as fraud, conflicts of interest, and inefficiencies. LBS governance programs include illustrative case studies demonstrating procurement governance in practice. For example, one case study highlights a multinational corporation that implemented a robust procurement governance framework, resulting in improved supplier selection processes, cost savings, and enhanced compliance with regulatory standards. Another case study explores how governance reforms in a public sector agency led to greater transparency and stakeholder trust in procurement activities. These real-world examples underscore the impact of governance on procurement outcomes, emphasizing the importance of integrating governance principles into purchasing decisions to achieve organizational excellence. Participants benefit from LBS’s global network, interactive learning environment, and access to cutting-edge research, fostering a comprehensive understanding of governance principles and their impact on organizational success. ## Subscribe to Our Governance Newsletter Stay informed and ahead in the field of governance by subscribing to our monthly Governance Newsletter. This newsletter delivers the latest insights, research highlights, expert interviews, and updates on governance best practices directly to your inbox. It is designed for business leaders, HR professionals, and governance practitioners seeking to deepen their understanding and stay current with evolving governance trends. **Subscribe now to receive:** - Exclusive articles and case studies on corporate governance and leadership - Invitations to webinars and events hosted by London Business School faculty - Updates on new governance programs and certifications - Practical tips for implementing effective governance strategies To subscribe, please fill out the form at: [https://www.london.edu/governance-newsletter-subscription](https://www.london.edu/governance-newsletter-subscription) or enter your email below:



Join a community of governance professionals committed to excellence and continuous learning. --- **Comments** Olaa Michael Thu, 08/24/2017 - 20:48 Tsehay Mon, 08/21/2017 - 23:46 Teja Wed, 07/12/2017 - 20:27 s.sangavi Sat, 07/08/2017 - 13:28 aman Thu, 05/04/2017 - 20:04 Abdinasir Sun, 10/23/2016 - 01:41 Axel Sun, 07/17/2016 - 10:07 Kayawe Patrrick Sun, 07/03/2016 - 23:04 Jahanzaib Marwat Fri, 05/13/2016 - 20:43 kusum Fri, 12/18/2015 - 01:38 Pages Add new comment
